summary: Indian soldiers avenge a deadly terrorist attack.

reviews.content: Master piece. Clean. Respectful.

Uri: The Surgical Strike is the dramatized account of the retaliation to the 2016 Uri attack by Indian forces against terrorist camps based in POK. It is a rousing Indian patriotic film which gets your heart thumping. The movie got stunning cinematography, good dialogues and is well paced. The action does become unrealistic at times with the hero doing impractical one on one combat, but overall the fight choreography looks modern and smart delivering us explosive scenes. The casting is superb, Vicky Kaushal shines in the lead and so does the supporting cast. It does feel like a propaganda film, and I feel there is nothing wrong about that.
 
PS: It is one of those movies were the best parts are shown in the trailer itself.

Uri: The Surgical Strikes is a taut thriller based on the real surgical strikes against terror camps based in Pakistan-Occupied-Kashmir. 

It is technically superior to almost any other Indian war movie made to date (Parmanu & Madras Cafe weren't strictly war movies). Some creative liberties have been taken, as is to be expected in a movie, and the action could have been better choreographed - though some of the hand-to-hand combat is superbly donw - but overall the fighting scenes take you right in the middle. 

Movies like these are much-needed. It doesn't rationalize, doesn't sympathize with terrorism or terrorists. Is not apologetic about our soldiers. Celebrates their incredible bravery.

Is it a propaganda movie? No. It would have become that much less effective had it tried to be a propaganda movie. Among real-life figures, it is Doval (played by Paresh Rawal) that the movie highlights rather than Modi. Your children need to, must, see the movie. A couple of scenes may be graphic, but no more than what kids are already exposed to. And yes, I guarantee you that there won't be a dry eye in the theater at one point.

Vicky Kaushal is excellent. Paresh Rawal nails it as the NSA, Ajit Doval. Rajit Kapoor plays Modi in very subdued shades, which actually work, since that keeps the focus on the action. Mohit Raina is terrific. Yami Gautam is there for the glamour Q. Swaroop Sampat is poignant. Rakesh Bedi is brilliant in a short cameo. And the little girl will break your heart.

To conclude, in the 40 or so years that I have memories of watching movies in theaters, this is the first time - EVER - that cries of "Jai Hind" & spontaneous applause rend the hall.

Uri -- fast-paced and gripping, with a host of excellent characters (and actors), adequate moments of levity, a wonderful soundtrack, great action direction, and beautiful camera shots -- is emblematic of Bollywood's maturation and ability to produce action-drama-military films to rival Hollywood blockbusters like Zero Dark Thirty and Munich, while managing to stop just short of being jingoistic. Thoroughly enjoyable from start to finish.

I'm an Indian and I'm not an Indian who takes sides of some political parties and writing reviews here like the (others).
We (Indians) watched too many war films based on different countries and their armies. Indian army as one of the greatest and strongest military power doesn't got luck to get any good film to showcase their contributions as Bollywood focused on typical dramas and love stories. As a movie lover, me and millions of movie lovers from India waiting since many years hoping to get a properly made film on Indian army and their missions with added Indian flavor of emotions. So, finally URI : The Surgical Strike is the perfect movie for Indian film makers to get inspired and start making movies on Indian army missions and contributions as the way this movie was made.
If you are an Indian waiting for a Indian military based movie expecting high standards of movie making and gives you so pride, then just go for it.
Even if you are not an Indian, everyone who likes war films  based on true events can watch this intense and interesting movie.

After a gap of may be 15 years I am seeing such a film. Salute to the Debutant Director Aditya Dhar whose direction is way above any other director in India. Simply mind blowing Cinematography and Garaphics edition. Vicky kaushal did an extra ordinary performance as major Vihan Singh Shergill. Apart from that Yami gautam, Paresh Rawal also did fantastic acting. Truly patriotic film that gives several goosebumps. A must watch film and i am going for the second time.

Since the 90s, J.P. Dutta has ruined war cinema for hindi films. The overly dramatic, passionate screaming and sentimental yearning for those left behind at home just became a cliche that was hard to shake off. Farhan Akhtar's Lakshya was the sole anomaly in this genre that was relatable, relevant and exemplary in its story telling. The advent of a new age of visionary artists who were past the phase of concocting stories with heroes larger than their characters has finally led to justice. 
Aditya Dhar's research on the Uri attacks must be thorough because there is no sensationalism to convince us about the events. Political agendas, media coverage and public sentiment are kept at subtle levels so as to keep the viewer engaged with the characters and their motivations. A fictional account of the operation and its preceding events it may well be but make no mistake; Uri showcases the Indian Army's tactical prowess and therefore, is a heavy action film. 

	Major Vihaan Shergill (Vicky Kaushal) has a proven track record of a successful surgical attack at the Myanmar border with his precise planning and execution. His ailing mother (Swaroop Sampat) keeps him posted in the Delhi headquarters, away from other action in Kashmir where his brother-in-law, Major Karan (Mohit Raina) is making the family proud. 
It is easy to invest in these characters with the sincerity depicted by the actors and the viewer's acute sense of what is coming. The Mahadev actor Mohit Raina, especially creates an impact in a few scenes as he takes charge of the camp's defense against the terrorist attack. Sprinting across the screen, dodging bullets and determined to kill the attackers, we root for this army hero to save the day from devastation. The film's title makes a timely appearance at the end of this intensity only to stir you at the Army's memorial service for the fallen soldiers like no tragedy has since Rang de Basanti. The attack was especially personal for Major Vihaan who motivates his commandos with a powerful element apart from their extraordinary individual capabilities - Rage. The encounter during the surgical strike is a visceral manifestation of this anger that is accurate enough with one bullet but there is no hesitation to portray the ruthlessness with which they shoot each militant more than once. This is a different Indian army that is shaken to its core and will show no mercy.
	As Paresh Rawal's Govind declares that with a surgical strike, a New India will tell the world that it is capable of not only entering enemy turf but also killing them on it, director Aditya Dhar's follow through on this bold statement is a far cry from the cliche, over-the-top dramatization of J.P. Dutta's army ventures. Precise to the point of the operation's planning, clinical in execution with exemplary cinematography, a tense and pulsating background score and the deployment of all modern arms and ammunition that support the valor of a spirited commando unit, Uri looks and feels like a Hollywood action film in its visual style and crisp editing.  
It is real, visceral, slick and engaging cinema that makes you respect the technical team that enabled it all. This is a no-nonsense retelling of the events that shook the nation and how the people in power made bold decisions to restore faith and pride in the citizens. 

	The performances by a competent cast are well confined to the tone and emotional depth of the characters in their situations. This is a critical area where a sound technical film can fall on its knees with miscasting and cliche performances but here, even a special appearance by Rakesh Bedi in an unusual role draws chuckles and not ridicule. Such is the impact of a fine cast that includes the likes of Paresh Rawal, Rajit Kapoor, Mohit Raina , Yami Gautam and the most credible Vicky Kaushal. 

	Aditya Dhar deserves a lot of praise for keeping it relevant to the new gen audience that now demands realism when depicting true events. Uri invokes patriotism without the usual chants and long speeches. It trades drama and hyperbole for surgical execution of a script that stays faithful to its topic. 
The victory song during the end credits is a high voltage anthem featuring Daler Mehendi of course, because who else can better vocalize passionate patriotism.

	4.701 on a scale of 1-5.

Lets start with the best.
Cinematography-Might be the best one you are gonna see in 2019.Yes sir framing lighting angles and best thing is the shadow work and night shots.
Vicky Kaushal- Spoilr ***Two shots to watch out for.One during the funeral.2nd the eyes he glared when he heard there will be a revenge ops.
Background Score-No one can be critical in there.***
Action-Never seen these type of perfectly executed army actions in Indian cinema.
Story-Well every one knows about the story of Surgical Strike. No new additions barring small perks.
Direction-Direction is commendable. Chapter wise distribution picking every events from 1st to last surgical strike and putting it in a compact 2 hours thriller guarantees goosebumps.And i would have put it in the 2nd best but one thing that bothered me is sudden end of the shots.When the excitement is building he ended it hurriedly and went to the next shot.These new approach in a Indian war movies i think may have worked with the millennial.I think it gave the perfect amount of patriotism and emotion and cut off the cringes.
Other things to notice-Though Aditya Dhar hit the every right spots of the audience by the rousing(many said jingoistic which i don't understand why the hell this word would have any meaning in a country which lacks patriotism in many region of the country) dialogues the silent expressions of every actors overpowered the the powerful dialogues.Which is a very good sign for Indian cinema.My rating is 5/5 10/10 99/100.

"Uri" is a very competently made action movie from Bollywood that can actually be taken seriously and always feels realistic and never over the top. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie on multiple levels. I thought every action scene in the movie was outstanding. I felt on the edge of my seat at many moments throughout. The movie is constantly breakneck and exciting. However,Â  I think why the action scenes are so effective are because there is an actual emotional connection to the characters. The movie chooses to take time with the exposition and that allowed me, as the viewer, to really empathize in the moments where the stakes felt dangerously high. The performances are also very good and were pretty realistic. This is a first-rate movie that is worth checking out. January is a traditionally bad month for Hollywood releases, so I'm glad this Bollywood movie got me to have an engaging experience at the movie theater in a month where I generally avoid going.
Amazing movie! So many parts resonated with all of us watching especially when Karan's daughter shouts the war cry! Everyone has delivered an excellent performance!

Movies like Tumbbad, Badhaai Ho, Andhadhun indicates an elusive renaissance going on within Indian cinema, URI: The Surgical Strike is no different. Itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s hard to believe that this has been Aditya Dharï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s first directional debut. Many will draw contrast with Kathryn Bigelowï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s Zero Dark Thirty or Clint Eastwoodï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s American Sniper, yet stories based on true events do have very similar take on chronicle.
The sheer effort coupled with brilliant acting, action & unforgettable title score makes this a must watch experience on big screen.
